I affirm that Homosexuals should be allowed to marry.
 
 I'd like to quickly make a few observations on the round:
 1) Allowing homosexuals to marry doesn't mandate any religious institution to recognize it. The affirmative only proposes that such marriages be recognized by the government, and open civil marriage to these people.
 2) Since the negative argues for a restriction on action, the burden is on him/her to provide direct harms that justify governmental prohibitions on an action. Since the default in a free society, is, well, freedom, it is assumed people should be allowed to take an action unless proven otherwise.
 
 Contention I: Marriage is a fundamental human right. The institution of marriage is rightly upheld by liberals and conservatives alike as a key social institution that should be relatively unhibited by federal regulation. As a general principle, any action to regulate which adult heterosexuals can marry would be regarded as obscene. The warrent for this is obvious, a government has no place telling people which individuals they designate as their life partner. In the United States, this is known as freedom of association, the government can no more designate who my wife will be than who my friends are. The fundamental, intimate relationships I form across my life are sacred to me, and cannot be breached. This regulatory prohibition holds even if a demonstrated social good can be demonstrated by micromanaging the institution. For example, while advances in genetics and bioengineering could concievably create "partnerships" most beneficial to society, in terms of the dynamics of the partners and their likely children, this would still not justify government regulation of the event. Despite all prospective gains that might come to the children, a union of Marilyn Vos Savant and Stephen Hawking should not be statutorly mandated. However, the only secular negative point comes down to just that. Because they allege that more "ideal" partnerships could be created, they seek to create and enforce regulations that mandate these types of partnerships to occur. This is morally equivilant to enforcing ideal partnerships on heterosexuals. The impact is that laws banning homosexual marriage are based off the false and inconsistently applied premise that marriage is an instrument of social change, not a sacred union between to individuals. If the latter outweigh's the former, then any union of people has to be recognized as a legitimate expression of individual choice. If the former outweighs the latter, then marraige is already dead in the water anyway.
 
 Contention II: Regulation of marriage is outside the purview of a legitiamate government. Before I go into this, I'd like to comment on some basic social contract theory. John Locke theorized about a hypothetical "state of nature" that existed prior to governments, where men could theoretically do anything, because they had no laws. They had absolute theoretical liberty. But in practice, they had little substantive liberty, b/c anything they did could be taken away by the bigger bully on the block. So we formed governments to protect "life, liberty, and property." Philosopher John Stuart Mill, in analyzing the proper role of government in his book "On Liberty" outlines his "harms principle" which says that people have absolute liberty up until the point it tangibly takes away the liberty of others. The warrent for this is clear, because under the Lockean model the only justification for taking away real liberty is to safeguard substantive liberty, any action which reduces substantive liberty (in other words, regulations that don't pertain to specific rights violations) is immoral. What the negative needs to prove, and it can't, is that allowing gays to marry has a tangible, non-discursive impact on the rights of another (presumably a heterosexual). (it should be noted that Mill specifically denied "bad" discourse as a legitmate harm under his theory, the action has to be tangible).
 
 Contention III: As a matter of equality, gays must be allowed to marry. When society undertakes to provide benefits to a group, "it must be provided to all, on equal terms" (Brown v. Board of Education, 1954). B/c of the numerous, diffuse benefits that marriage provides, both tangible (vistitation rights, tax deductions etc.) and abstract (legitimacy, membership in the community), to specifically exclude a class of human's from these benefits is a denial of the basic maxim that "all [hu]men[s] are created equal." Nor do civil unions provide solvency. Civil Unions fall victim to being akin to the seperate but equal doctrine rejected by the courts in the 1950s. As the court ruled in Sweatt v. Painter, even if in a "seperate but equal" system TANGIBLE benefits are identical, the intangible issues, such as prestige, reputation, membership in community etc. make seperation inherently unequal. The multi-tiered structure that civil unions would be part of would inherently be seen as a second class institution, created an "us vs. them" seperation that only serves to reinforce discriminative mindsets in America. To turn a likely negative argument, opening marriage to gays is actual a positive tool of social change, because it destigmatizes the community and allows them to have full participation in society.
 
 In sum, the affirmative claims the following:
 1) No one can tell an individual who they are allowed to form intimate relationships with, whether those relationships are platonic or not.
 2) Governmental Theory doesn't allow for the negative proposal.
 3) Even buying that the social situation is a legitimate issue, the affirmative offers comparative benefits via destigimatization and rejection of discriminatory mindsets. The alternative offered by the negative is at best multi-tiered and socially divisive, and at worst blantently unequal.
 
 For those reasons, I affirm.
